title: offsite backups
description:
# Home Assistant Offsite Backups to Backblaze B2 (S3-compatible)

## What we’re doing
You already have scheduled local HA backups. Goal is to **automatically copy those backups offsite** to **Backblaze B2**, without touching Google auth and without “AWS account” nonsense.

We’ll use an HA integration that plugs into Home Assistant’s **native backup system**, but targets **any S3-compatible provider** (including Backblaze B2). :contentReference[oaicite:0]{index=0}

---

## Prereqs
- Home Assistant OS (or a Supervisor-based install) with UI access
- A Backblaze account (you have this)
- Optional but recommended: HACS installed (for easiest install path) :contentReference[oaicite:1]{index=1}

---

## Step 1 — Create a Backblaze B2 bucket + scoped key

### 1) Create a bucket
In Backblaze B2:
- Create a new **Bucket**
- Keep it **Private**
- Pick a region (whatever is closest / default for your account)

### 2) Note your S3 endpoint + region
Backblaze’s S3 endpoint format is:

- `https://s3.<region>.backblazeb2.com` :contentReference[oaicite:2]{index=2}

Example endpoints are also shown in the HA community integration post (e.g. `https://s3.us-west-001.backblazeb2.com`). :contentReference[oaicite:3]{index=3}

### 3) Create an “Application Key” for backups (recommended)
Create an application key limited to this bucket (principle of least privilege):
- Save **Key ID** + **Application Key** (secret)
- Don’t use your account’s “master” keys for HA

---

## Step 2 — Install “S3 Compatible Backup” in Home Assistant

This is a **custom integration** intended specifically to extend HA backups to S3-compatible storage (Backblaze B2 included). :contentReference[oaicite:4]{index=4}

### Option A (recommended): Install via HACS
From the integration’s instructions: :contentReference[oaicite:5]{index=5}
1. Open **HACS → Integrations**
2. Menu (⋮) → **Custom repositories**
3. Add this repo URL:
   - `https://github.com/bauer-group/IP-HomeassistantS3CompatibleBackup` :contentReference[oaicite:6]{index=6}
4. Category: **Integration**
5. Install
6. **Restart Home Assistant**

### Option B: Manual install (if you hate HACS)
The project also documents a manual `custom_components` install path. :contentReference[oaicite:7]{index=7}
(Use this only if you’re already comfortable managing `/config/custom_components`.)

---

## Step 3 — Configure the integration (connect HA ↔ B2)

In Home Assistant:
1. **Settings → Devices & Services → Add Integration**
2. Search: **S3 Compatible Backup** :contentReference[oaicite:8]{index=8}
3. Fill in:
   - **Access Key ID**: (Backblaze Key ID)
   - **Secret Access Key**: (Backblaze Application Key)
   - **Bucket Name**: your bucket
   - **Endpoint URL**: `https://s3.<region>.backblazeb2.com` :contentReference[oaicite:9]{index=9}
   - **Region**: the region string (the `<region>` part)
   - **Prefix** (optional): default is fine (`homeassistant`) :contentReference[oaicite:10]{index=10}

Result: your backups land in a predictable folder structure in the bucket (prefix/backups + metadata). :contentReference[oaicite:11]{index=11}

---

## Step 4 — Make sure HA backups are configured the way you want

Home Assistant’s backup system supports automatic backups from the UI, and the backup action `backup.create_automatic` uses those settings. :contentReference[oaicite:12]{index=12}

In HA:
- **Settings → System → Backups → Backup settings**
  - Set schedule (daily/weekly)
  - Set retention (e.g., keep last 30)
  - **Set a backup password/encryption** if you want “cloud bucket = safe even if leaked”

> Tip: For offsite, “encrypted backups” is worth it.

---

## Step 5 — Validate it end-to-end (don’t skip)
1. Trigger a manual backup (from the Backups UI)
2. Wait for upload
3. Confirm you see new objects in B2
4. Download one backup locally and keep it as your “known good” snapshot

---

## Step 6 — Monitoring / failure alerts (recommended)
HA exposes an event entity for automatic backup status and provides an example automation to notify on failures. :contentReference[oaicite:13]{index=13}

If you want, we can wire an iOS push notification when automatic backup fails using:
- `event.backup_automatic_backup` and its `failed_reason` attribute :contentReference[oaicite:14]{index=14}

---

## Cost expectations (B2 is basically free at HA scale)
Backblaze B2 pricing is typically:
- ~$0.005/GB-month storage
- First 10GB storage free (common on B2 pricing pages / posts) :contentReference[oaicite:15]{index=15}

At “HA backup” sizes, you’re usually talking **cents/month**, not dollars.

---

## Quick checklist
- [ ] B2 bucket created (private)
- [ ] Scoped application key created + stored safely
- [ ] S3 Compatible Backup integration installed (HACS or manual)
- [ ] Integration configured with correct endpoint + region
- [ ] HA automatic backups configured + retention set
- [ ] One manual backup verified in B2
- [ ] (Optional) Backup failure notification automation added

---
close_reason: Completed: S3 Compatible Backup integration installed, configured with Backblaze B2, test backup verified in bucket, failure notification automation created

title: cook mode overnight
description: twice overnight cook mode was enabled. i woke up at about 3:30 am and toggled it off via the button. when i woke up around 8am it was toggled on again. inestigate the logs to identify the issue

comments.author: john.allen
comments.text:
## Investigation Findings (2026-01-02)

### Timeline of overnight cook mode toggles
| Time (ET) | Event |
|-----------|-------|
| 6:14 PM Jan 1 | Cook mode OFF (last normal use) |
| 3:17 AM Jan 2 | Kitchen button (Matter) went **unavailable** |
| 3:43 AM Jan 2 | Kitchen button came back → cook mode turned ON |
| 3:50 AM Jan 2 | User turned it OFF via button |
| 4:51 AM Jan 2 | Kitchen button went **unavailable** again |
| 6:42 AM Jan 2 | Kitchen button came back → cook mode turned ON |

### Root cause
When Matter buttons reconnect after being unavailable, HA fires a state change event. The `automation.kitchen_button` triggers on any state change to `event.smart_button_button`. The `event_type` attribute retains its last value (`multi_press_1`), so the automation runs `script.toggle_cooking`.

### Broader context - Matter network instability
Multiple Matter devices went unavailable overnight (2-4 AM ET):
- 2:01 AM - beltalowda-net (network equipment)
- 2:03 AM - Roborock vacuum
- 2:05 AM - Ember mug
- 3:17 AM - Kitchen button (Matter)
- 4:01 AM - Bathroom Lamp (Matter)
- 4:02 AM - Living Room Overhead Thread
- 4:05 AM - Kitchen counter switch (Matter)
- 4:08 AM - Bedroom button (Matter)

Both Matter buttons went unavailable. The bedroom button automation also triggered on reconnect but didn't cause visible issues.

### Open questions
1. Why did Matter devices start going unavailable overnight? This is new behavior.
2. Possible causes: HomePod Mini (Thread border router) firmware update, Apple Home changes, WiFi/Thread interference

### Potential fix (not applied)
Add condition to button automations to ignore state changes from unavailable:
```yaml
conditions:
  - condition: template
    value_template: "{{ trigger.from_state.state not in ['unavailable', 'unknown'] }}"
```

### Status
Leaving open to monitor. Will revisit if issue recurs.
